captions.text:
- What about you?
- In a minute.
I have to close the launch door.

I thought I heard you
talking to someone.

Well, you handled that
very neatly.

I mean drugs, poisons,
barbiturates, eh?

If you came here to clown,
you may as well leave.

Sometimes you clown
without knowing it.

Haven't you had a try
with a rope or hammer?

Haven't you thrown an inkpot
at the devil, like Luther did?

Lock her in, press the button
and it's over.

Try to launch it from the corridor
so you won't get burned.

- What was that?
- Not for certain.

But we've established
a theory at least.

You saw the materialization
of your conception of her.

The visits began
after we started

To test the Ocean, we initiated
a concentrated surface sweep

You are fortunate. The woman
is part of your past.

What if you had seen
something you never knew,

something out of the recesses
of your soul?
What are you trying to say?

The Ocean responded to our probe
with one of its own,

directed to our brain, and
extracted some bits of memory.

- Will she come back?
- She will... and she won't.

- Hari-2.
- Any number of doubles is possible.
I got scared. I acted like...

Don't berate yourself.
One Guibarian's enough.

Will you sign the report
I'm going to make up?
Night time is a blessing up here.
It reminds me of the earth.

Let's paste strips
of paper on the air vents.

Guibarian's invention -
the essence of simplicity -

Sartorius made jibes at us
but he has his own thing.
We can meet in the library later.

I've prepared a list of books
for you.

- It's so dark.
- Come, don't be afraid.
The door opens the other way.

I saw you weren't here
and I got scared.

Speak louder.
What are you doing now?

Sartorius wants to see us
in the lab.
I'll see what I can do.

- You are late.
- I couldn't get any sooner.

Oh how beautiful!
Are they yours?

As far as I understand,
they are structured...

- Let's call them Visitors.
- Very well.

Whereas our structure is
atomically integrated,

I guess Solaris' magnetic field
stabilizes them.

I used acid to burn the blood
but it regenerates.

Self-regeneration?
Well, what do you know!

In a word, immortality.
Faust's problem.

Are you qualified to perform
an autopsy?

- I've told you she's my wife.
- It's more humane

to experiment on them
than on our earth's rabbits.
It'd be like cutting off my leg.

D'you feel pain when you
broke through the door?

If I ever catch you attempting
anything on her...

Your attitude is absurd,
but at least you've established

an emotional contact with them
through her.

- What? Envious?
- Perhaps I am envious.

No, there's no envy in you,
nor guilt.

When you turn into a hopeless
cripple, a basket case,

- Toward whom are you guilty?
- You, among others.

Dad shot most of it.
I did some bits.
I don't know my own self.

I close my eyes and can't
remember my face. Can you?

- Do you know yourself?
- Yes, all humans do.

That woman in the fur coat,
how she hated me!

She died long ago,
before we ever met.

Why are you trying to make
a fool of me?

I came over for tea,
she told me to leave.

So I left at once.
I remember it very well.

And that was the last time
I saw you.

Why didn't you take me
with you?

I was passing by and thought
you were up.

The rate of regeneration
has slowed,

we can be rid of Them
for 2-3 hours.

And you come at night
to tell me about it?
I'll tell you why I came.
We think that since the Ocean

extracts Visitors from us
during our sleep, in might be

in our interest to communicate
our waking thoughts to it.

Perhaps, it will spare us
all these apparitions.

More of your idiotic preaching
on the greatness of science?

We'll integrate the beam
with the brainwaves of one of us.
One of us means me, of course?

What if I'd want her to die
or disappear?
Give it all to that jelly.

Sartorius has another project,
involving annihilators.

It was my idea about
the encephalogram.

Tomorrow is my birthday.
You are invited.

- You just want us to patch it up.
- Yes, I do.
So she knows how to sleep.
See you tomorrow in the library.
We'll set up the table there.
At least there are no windows.
Now let's go and see Sartorius.

- You don't love me.
- Stop it, Hari.

- We need to talk.
- About what?

Won't you help me understand
where I came from?

- I think you know.
- What are you saying?
and you can't tell me now,
perhaps you will one day, huh?
I wish you had told me.
How did you go on living?

- Were you in love with someone?
- I don't know.

- Did you ever think of me?
- Sometimes, yes.
the worse it will be - for you.
I packed my things and left.

She didn't say it in so many words.
When you've lived

with a person long enough,
words are unnecessary.

I was sure those were just words
but then I remembered

I brought it from the lab
and told her how it works.

I wanted to see her
but then thought

it would look like I had taken
her words seriously.

On the third day
I could wait no longer.
When I came she was already dead.

I saw a trace of a shot
on her arm.

I guess she felt
I didn't really love her.

It's not only inside me.
It comes from far away.

You're exactly an hour
and a half late.
And man needs nights for sleeping.
man has lost the gift of sleep.

When I sleep, I know
no fear, no hope,

Praise be
to the gentle sleep creator.

That currency used by all,
these universal scales

equalizing shepherd and king,
fool and scholar.
it smacks too much of death.

Never in your life, Sancho, have you
pronounced a more gracious speech.

That's very nice, but perhaps
you'll let me say a few words.

To his devotion to duty!
To science and to Snaut!

In this situation
both mediocrity and genius

we do not want to conquer
any cosmos.

We want to expand the earth
as far as the cosmos.

We don't know what to do
with other worlds,

We're trying hard to make contact.
We're doomed to failure.
and which we really don't need.

In memory of him. Though
what he did was out of fear.

He thought it was happening
only to him.

Your heart-rending moaning is
quasi-Dostoyevsky, nothing more.

- Who are you to judge us?
- I know why I'm here.

Nature created man so
he might gain knowledge.

Marching toward truth
man is condemned to knowledge.
The rest is of no consequence.

Except for your tryst with your
ex nothing seems to interest you.

You're lolling in bed out
of ideological considerations
thinking that you do your job well.

Everything has to end someday.
Let's drink to Guibarian.

Are you suggesting
Guibarian wasn't a man?

Stop it, Chris. All we need is
to begin quarreling.

of the three of you Chris seems
to follow what he believes in.

In these inhuman conditions
he alone acts human.

You two pretend
that your so-called Visitors -

is this what you call us? -
are a kind of pest,

But they are part of you,
your conscience.

Perhaps he needs me as a defense
against himself.

It doesn't matter why humans
love, it's different for everyone.
It's you. Oh how I loathe you!

- I must ask you -
- No. I'm a woman...

You're not even a human being!
You must understand -

you are still capable
of understanding.

There's no Hari.
She is dead.

A mechanical repletion
of the form! A copy!
I am becoming a human being.
I can feel as deeply as you.

I already can live
without him.

We lose our dignity
and humanity.

You're very human,
each in your own way.
I hope I'm not in the way.

After all, can't a man
who'd give up his life
for this damned contact to see

what this is all about
get drunk?

Do you believe in our mission,
Kelvin?

I'll stay up a while.
I'm not going to sleep.

is trying to get
a remedy for immortality.
Look, let's open the bottom hatches
Only who shall we call to?

Or, better still, pray to It.
Hey, what's up?

I closed the door to the library.
She's alone there.

Go to her.
I feel a lot better.

there'll be 30 seconds
of a weightless flight.

Sorry, honey, I was lost
in my thoughts.
The worst is yet to come.

The more she's with you,
the more human she becomes.

- You should act like Sartorius.
- Thanks for the advice.
What are you going to do?

Then what? You'll leave
the station?

She can live only here,
and you know that.

- I love her.
- Love whom? Her?

We might change the orbit
and she can come anytime.

Don't convert a scientific quest
into a love story.

I felt she'd come
to a bad end.

I can't get used
to all these resurrections.

- Don't talk, Hari.
- I'm not Hari.

Maybe the Ocean sent you
to torture me.

Who cares about whys?
You are more to me

than all scientific truths
that have ever existed.

- Do I look very much like her?
- No.

- You can't stand looking at me.
- Stop it.
I'll not return to the Earth.
We'll live here, on the station.
harms our life. No, it doesn't.

He suffered as he couldn't
love mankind in totality.

How much time has passed
since then?

I can't make out...
Help me.

Love is a feeling
you can experience

One can explain
the idea of love

but you love that
which you can lose.

had no way of reaching love.
See what I mean?

There are so few of us,
a few million at the most.

Perhaps the reason we are here
is to learn

to perceive human beings
as a reason to love.
Guibarian didn't die out of fear.

He died out of shame.
Shame, the feeling

It's running slow again.
I'll set it right.
You seem to lead a strange life.

You're sloppy, you don't
take care of yourself.
How'd you get into this state?

Chris, I'm sorry
I had to deceive you

This is the only solution
for both of us.
I asked them to do it.

Later, Chris.
You must rest now.

Annihilation. An explosion
of light, a burst of wind.

We quarreled so often
those last days.

why are we being tortured
that way?

we've lost sense
of the cosmic.
Ancient man had no such problem.

He'd have never questioned
the Cosmos: Why? What for?
not a single Visitor has come.

Strange things are happening
to the Ocean.

Islands are forming
on Its surface.
At first one, then a few more.

Are you telling me
It took us in?
But at least we can hope now.

After so many years
on the station,

do you still feel as clearly
your link with the earth's life?

You really do ask
personal questions.

I suppose next you'll ask me
about the meaning of life.

When a man is happy,
the meaning of life

and other 'eternal' themes
rarely interest him.

These questions should be asked
at the end of one's life.

Who knows when your life
will end?

Nobody is sure,
that's why we are racing.

Don't be in a hurry.
The happiest guys are those

who never bother asking
those cursed questions.

We question life
to seek out some meaning.

Yet all simple human truths
have their own mystery.

Perhaps you're right. But I can't
help thinking about it.

like knowing the day
of your death.

Not knowing this day is what
makes us immortal.

What next?
Back to the Earth?

Life'll return to normal.
I'll have new ideas, new friends,

but I'll never be able
to get involved deeply.

Do I have a right
to miss the chance -

even if imaginary - to come
into contact with the Ocean

to which my race is striving
to throw a thread of understanding?

Among the things and objects
both of us touched

and which still remember
our breathing.
But I don't have this hope.

The only thing left for me
is wait.

I guess it's time for you
to return to the Earth.

comments.author: Snowdenbleep

comments.text:
This is a beautiful and an immensely hopeful movie about suffering and the 
ability of love to reach into the eternal.  It needs a few viewings, about 
every two years perhaps.  It was made long before much had been written 
about Quantum Theory and the ability of the viewer to affect what he sees 
and yet the fact that the characters can create what happens through their 
consciousness reflects Quantum Theory.  Chris finds out that if we live 
with love and compassion, only then can we create what is worthwhile, only 
then can we move forward in this vale of soul-making here on earth. Here on 
earth we are never allowed to see God, only occasionally might we feel his 
love and compassion, like the light coming through the round windows of the 
spacecraft.  But when we feel compassion and connectedness with the rest of 
humanity, whether it is living and sharing in the suffering of others or 
whatever, then we grow.  Chris does go home after learning to love his 
wife.  The ocean  then encourages him with one more vision it sends him to 
go back to his father.  Then he goes home to his father, whom he will tell 
he loves before his father dies and leaves this earth with the knowledge 
his son loves him. The spacecraft is suffused with the mystery of our quest 
to find out more about life.  But to complete the circle, we need peace, 
which is why Chris returns home.﻿
comments.author: Emily West

comments.text:
+Emily West Quantum Theory was developed in the 30s, Quantum 
Electrodynamics was developed in 50s. Associating Quantum Theory with 
consciousness is a pseudoscience, it is often disparagingly called Quantum 
Woo.

comments.text:
I don't feel this is SF. It is a reality that our interest, desire and 
notion come true. Just it takes some time - a decade. let's say our God 
resides in a different planet (far away) so that it takes 5 years to send 
our aim  and wish and it takes another 5 years to recieve 'yes' message 
from God. Make a wish, then your life will guide you and show you what you 
have aspired in a way that you can't imagine with your head and in a way 
that you've never planned. Just note that it wouldn't be immediate, and it 
just takes a decade. It's our time-scale. If your wish is more clear, 
definite, concentrated and well-pointed, you will see it sooner in your 
reality. Trust me. That's a power of one.﻿

comments.author: Katerina 11

comments.text:
Im Russian. when i was 16-17 i watched this movie first time.I couldn't 
finish watching it as I was bored to tears...This movie was made back in 
1973, the year i was born. Then i watched it again when I was in my late 
20-s. the second "attempt" was more successful, I finally purchased the 
whole version with Engl. subs about 5 years ago. The story is incredibly 
painful and incredibly beautiful at the same time. The main character, 
Chris, arrives to the station which is influenced by the mysterious Ocean 
which is capable of "reproducing" the people who were long gone on Earth 
life, but as those long gone people still remained in people's hearts and 
memories, they "reappear" again. Chris wife committed suicide many years 
ago leaving Chris with the feeling of guilt and confusion, loss and pain 
for years. She felt emotionally neglected by him in real life....Anyways, 
this movie is really difficult to just explain like this, its complicated. 
The Ocean works with human consciousness...letting "station" people meet 
again with the ones they wronged or hurt in Earth life, as if they would 
have another chance to resolve the conflict, or experience love in more 
deep mature and humanly compassionate way as it is depicted with Chris and 
his gone wife...I recommend watching this movie seriously, this is a 
different kind of science fiction. This movie became precious to me from 
all perspectives...I watch it nearly once in two-three years period, and I 
love it.﻿

Chris says he can never become involved with anyone deeply again.  Then the 
ocean show him the vision of his father waiting for him in his house in the 
woods, we know the ocean shows this to him because we see it surrounding 
the island where this takes place.  Chris realizes his father loves him and 
is then able to return back to reality...only love makes life bearable.

comments.author: sasancohen

comments.text:
24:54

The painting in the background was done by Andrei Rublyov, the Medieval 
Christian painter portrayed in the Tarkovsky film of the same name. Artists 
tend to use recurring themes in their works, its interesting how Tarkovsky 
would use the same painting in a movie set in the past and one set in the 
future.

I guess seeing one or two classics isn't enough...you must see an entire 
director's repertoire in order to even understand one of their films. 
Anderi Tarkovsky, you are one of the best; few director's can parallel your 
talent. Thanks for another great!﻿

comments.author: gorantrevise

comments.text:
Well I watched the first part and 17 minutes of this part so far and all I 
can say is it has more interesting elements than the 2002 version but its 
slower than a snail on prozac and I have found my attention wandering a lot 
- This would make a great mini-series but its too long for a decent film... 
with smart editing and cropping some BS out it would be truly great...this 
looks like ulétimately its good but not great and only marginally better 
than the 2002 version

It seems to have the obvious flaw of the re-make as well - Why dont we see 
Chris recording anything? Surely he would not get sent on the station and 
not be expected to report back frequently too? And why was he sent alone? 
Lets send just one person there...makes sense DOH

OH I liked the bit with the door where it buckles when Hari trying to get 
through

I like long films if there is going to be some "money shot" or wtf type or 
sublime revelation ending...this is why 2001 stands the best of 
time...Kubrick knew you have to let the viewers have something after having 
the patience to sit through slow stuff...so we got the "trip" ending with 
the Starchild and all that other crazy stuff...unless the ending is 
radically different from the 2002 version we will have a flat ending﻿
comments.author: Jack Luminous

comments.text:
+lozinja

The ending is weirder but more "poetic" than the remake  but I was left 
thinking "is that it?" - I am just not seeing this as a classic movie - A 
good movie for sure but viewers should be advised of its flaws (imho as 
someone else might think the pacing is brilliant etc etc)
comments.author: Jack Luminous

comments.text:
Yes, those films are slow. But my feelings and thoughts are still too fast 
to fill the gaps with so many "what ifs" ... After film I don't feel too 
good alone in my dark house. What if there is someone who is listening to 
our feelings and thoughts? What if he/it will try to help? Or simply will 
try to do some experiment with us - just as we do?
I know one thing - reality has much bigger fantasy than I :-)
Everything is possible - but most of it will never happen :-)
comments.author: dmatej79

comments.text:
I kind of agree with a lot of what you say and it is glacially paced this 
film; however as you say yourself you hoped there would be a pay off at the 
end. It would have been good to read a review you wrote after seeing the 
whole film. For me the ending really is one of the most memorable of any 
film I've ever seen; truly mesmerising and adds to the creepiness and 
elevates this way above the 2002 remake. I just think Tarkovsky's film has 
much more depth than Sodabergh's more accessible vision focusing on the 
love story. Though you have to be in right frame of mind and be patient 
with the Tarkovsky.
comments.author: lozinja

comments.text:
It was not his dead friend but his dead wife. And what he saw was not his 
dead wife but a projection of his jumble of feelings about her mixed up 
with feelings he had for others. This is a subtle movie and trying to look 
at it otherwise is only going to lead to boredom and frustration.
comments.author: clrsky58

comments.text:
You are right: you do not "get" it and forcing yourself to view it for a 
school project is not likely to help you apprecitate the subtlety of the 
movie.

I am just trying to watch the second part and I feel exactly the way you do 
:/ Of course, having read the book first (half of it though, I can't make 
myself finish it) makes understanding the movie easier. I am supposed to 
write an essay on this movie, if not I wasn't even ever going to bother 
watching it. I'm not saying it's a bad movie but I don't know what's all 
the fuss about. maybe I just don't get it. I think in a way, we are all 
Chrises that are being followed by Haris even here on Earth

comments.text:
The existential way that this plays out, along with the metaphysical 
aspects to it are absolutely beautiful to watch. The mirror that solaris 
mimics throughout the film sometimes leaves the viewer confused as to who 
is real and what the ocean has replicated.

comments.text:
Just saw this classic. To me its simply about the comfort we seek in the 
illusion of peace and happiness. After all reality is what which perceive 
it to be. The theme of suicide is a mere droplet in an ocean of ideas this 
film is. And the 1st half built up quite well - in fact its actually a bit 
more engaging than the heavier part 2. Sorry you didn't like it. Maybe Fast 
and Furious 6 is more your kinda thing -_-
comments.author: poontang3zizo

comments.text: Действительно кино ,а не то многое, что сейчас им называют.
comments.author: den vasilev

comments.text:
Watched it finally for first time. The beginning was very slow and 
tiresome, probably more interesting after you watched the movie at least 
once. Failed to catch the main message of the film. Need to watch it 
another couple of times to fully understand it. Suicide is still a mystery 
to me, I feel no empathy, neither for Chris nor for his dead friend. And I 
was caught in finding a rational explanation for Hari's consciousness, so 
ruined the joy for myself.
comments.author: 3tastudent

comments.text:
Люди преступны от природы, но слабы. На зло способны только сильные, 
избранные. Зло - это ступень. Переступаешь ее - освобождаешься. — Ну а 
добро? — А добро... это такая простая ловушка.... для дураков. — Так 
недалеко и до гражданской войны. — А она и не кончалась с момента 
сотворения мира... Божьи войны. Этот диалог из книги и в фильме тоже 
прозвучал, насколько я знаю, но пересмотрев так и не услышал! Подскажите 
почему?

comments.author: Андрея Белчев

comments.text:
Great films of ANY era are dependent on more than just production elements; 
they're treatments for ASTROLOGICAL peculiarities, placing the Earth at 
THEIR times—that can't be reproduced by throwing money at remakes, or 
trying to duplicate technique. The stars have literally moved on. Indeed, 
filmmakers would be better today, tapping into poignant energies CURRENTLY 
available, and launching from that EQUALLY tantalizing escarpment, taking 
time away from computers by sticking heads out of Windows™.
comments.author: MrMajorTime

comments.text:

comments.author: Cornelius Augustus Von Meyerbeer III

comments.text:
I'm not American, but that is a very stupid and ignorant thing to say. 
Tartakovsky was influenced by the great American director Stanley Kubrick. 
Other great American filmmakers: Francis Ford Copolla, Martin Scorsese, 
John Ford, DW Griffith, Orson Welles, Nicholas Ray, Busby Berkely, Chuck 
Jones, Bob Clampett, and Val Lewton. Educate yourself.
comments.author: Cornelius Augustus Von Meyerbeer III

comments.text:
I've read the book - Solaris by Stanislaw Lem and have seen the new version 
of this movie with George Clooney. But I always wanted to watch this movie 
- the old version. Now after watching it, I can tell you the new version of 
this movie doesn't come close to the old version, in any way. This is one 
of my favourite of all times. So is the book. Thanks for uploading the 
movie. :)
